image.altText: Headshot of a smiling Indigenous man in a patterned shirt

items.synopsis: While many say they are devastated by the No result in Saturday's referendum, First Nations leaders around the country are also hopeful that positive change can result.

title.children: Indigenous Australians look to the future with hope despite Voice  referendum defeat

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, but the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly in inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: A clear pattern has emerged in the way cities have voted in this referendum

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks in front of the Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags inside parliament house

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese vows to forge a new way forward to close the gap in life outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians, after voters resoundingly reject a Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Not the end of the road': PM accepts referendum result, maps path forward for Indigenous recognition

image.altText: A huge crowd yells and holds up blue signs that say 'Vote no'.

items.synopsis: The federal government will be preparing for a difficult week of questions over what happens next, now that the Voice to Parliament has been rejected at a referendum.

title.children: Australians have rejected the Voice to Parliament. What happens now?

image.altText: a surfer with his surfboard on the floor votes at a polling centre in  bondi for the indigenous voice to parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Support for Yes was strongest in the inner suburbs, while the majority of outer suburban, regional and rural voters said No. But analysts say the reasons why voters rejected the referendum question is more complex.

title.children: Voice result reveals more than just Australia's country-city divide

image.altText: Black Mountain Tower in Canberra appears through mist.

items.synopsis: Canberrans voted at odds with the rest of Australia — again. Their approval of the Voice joins a list of other moments that set the capital apart.

title.children: Is the ACT really 'the progressive heart of the nation' for voting Yes?

image.altText: Close up of Aunty Jill Gallagher

items.synopsis: After the Voice to Parliament failed to gain support, campaigners on both sides are calling for kindness towards Indigenous communities.

title.children: Victorians react to the Voice to Parliament referendum outcome

image.altText: A man wearing a black shirt with a red and white slogan

items.synopsis: As the dust settles on the Voice referendum, WA state political reporter Keane Bourke explains how the west was lost, and what it means going forward for First Nations people.

title.children: WA was the final voice to say No. But the pathway ahead towards change is far from clear

image.altText: A close up, blurry photo of a man with a moustache and brown eyes.

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Force's top spokesman says the killing of senior Hamas members is a "top priority". But analysts say tracking down these leaders will be complicated, and even if Israel is able to "eliminate" its targets, there is no guarantee it will bring an end to this war.

title.children: 'Israel has to destroy Gaza if they want to destroy Hamas': The hunt for the terror commanders

image.altText: Chris Hipkins bows his head while standing at the lectern.

items.synopsis: New Zealand Labour took a step to the centre, and their supporters walked in the opposite directions.

title.children: As Australia rejects the Voice, NZ swings towards Te Pati Maori

image.altText: The back of a woman with a vest saying Australian Official on it

items.synopsis: Repatriation flights that were scheduled to evacuate Australians out of Israel this weekend have been cancelled, as residents in Gaza City scramble to leave in anticipation of a ground invasion.

title.children: Repatriation flights cancelled for Australians as Israel deadline for Gaza evacuations passes — as it happened

image.altText: A mobile artillery unit firing.

items.synopsis: Israel's chief military spokesman says that Israeli military is going to strike Gaza City "very soon".

title.children: Israel readies troops for invasion as Gaza residents flee their homes

image.altText: Thomas Mayo Marcia Langton

items.synopsis: Prominent Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo says he does not blame the Australian public for the Voice to Parliament referendum being defeated.

title.children: Yes campaigner says 'reconciliation is dead' as Voice referendum is defeated

image.altText: A defaced electoral sign.

items.synopsis: In the lead-up to the Voice to Parliament referendum, South Australia was widely described as a crucial state for the Yes campaign — instead, more than 60 per cent of voters backed the No camp.

title.children: SA rejects Voice to Parliament as overwhelming majority backs No vote

image.altText: An older man stands in water. He has a white towel around his waist and no shirt. he has tanned skin and some wrinkles. He frown

items.synopsis: Longtime regulars at Pelican Point on Lake Bonney, a designated clothing-optional beach, are frustrated over a lack of access following major floods and joint-management wrangling.

title.children: Naturists 'completely locked out' of South Australian nude beach

image.altText: Paul Fuller's business's bank accounts were drained of $1.2 million by hackers.

items.synopsis: A hacker who stole $1.2 million from a family business already had confidential information before the theft occurred. Those in the field say cybercrime is rapidly evolving, and small businesses are facing increasing and targeted threats.

title.children: Paul's family business lost $1.2 million to a hacker. It's a sign cyber crime is evolving

image.altText: a hand holds a magnifying glass with the picture of a bed bug up to a well made hotel room bed

items.synopsis: News of France's recent bed bug infestation has triggered phantom itches and vivid memories of my own encounter with bed bugs in Paris more than a decade ago.

title.children: They crawl! They bite! Remembering my Parisian bed bug nightmare

image.altText: A pile of referendum ballot papers being counted

items.synopsis: Antony Green projects a majority No vote nationally and in four states. Our full results guide breaks down the numbers.

title.children: Voice referendum results: Follow the count across the country

image.altText: Two women, one blonde and one with red curly hair.

items.synopsis: In a digitally connected world, one in three Australians still report feeling lonely. From dinner parties with strangers to pledging to have a blind "friendship date" every week for a year, these women are finding creative solutions when it comes to making new friends as an adult.

title.children: Friendship blind dates and dinner with strangers: How to make friends as an adult

image.altText: Arati Nair, a psychology student is in her university campus. She is dressed in black and is wearing glasses.

items.synopsis: Cultural understanding and sensitivity can make a "huge difference" for culturally and linguistically diverse people seeking help for mental health issues.

title.children: When Arati met a counsellor for help, she was told to read a bible and forget everything else

image.altText: Yes campaign for Indigenous Voice to Parliament launches

items.synopsis: Yes campaigners say now is "not the time to dissect the reasons" the Voice to Parliament referendum was defeated.

title.children: Indigenous Yes campaigners call for week of silence to grieve 'tragic' referendum defeat

image.altText: A woman holding her baby standing in front of a school building

items.synopsis: Western Australians were still lining up to cast their votes for more than an hour and a half after the national result was known – here’s how that played out.

title.children: Western Australians learn of Voice referendum defeat while waiting in line to vote

image.altText: Scoot plane wing seen from an airport terminal

items.synopsis: The man allegedly told a cabin crew member "I have a bomb", forcing the flight from Singapore to turn back under fighter jet escort.

title.children: Australian man charged after alleged bomb threat on Perth-bound flight

image.altText: A firefighter stares down a blaze

items.synopsis: Fellow crew members tried to help a volunteer firefighter with a defibrillator until ambulance officers arrived but the man died in what RFS Commissioner Rob Rogers says was the "ultimate sacrifice".

title.children: Volunteer firefighter dies after medical episode while tackling NSW fire

image.altText: Sam Clipperton celebrates on Think About It

items.synopsis: Think About It wins the $20 million Everest at Randwick, beating I Wish I Win and Private Eye in the world's richest thoroughbred race on turf.

title.children: 'Unbelievable' Think About It wins $20 million Everest at Randwick

image.altText: Jack Darling kicks a goal

items.synopsis: West Coast have taken to social media to hit out at reports suggesting the AFL club is willing to trade premiership forward Jack Darling.

title.children: Eagles take to social media to shut down Darling rumours

image.altText: Palestinians drive down a road on motorbikes, cars, tractors and utility trucks

items.synopsis: Thousands of Palestinians flee to southern Gaza in search of refuge after Israel warns them to leave before an expected ground offensive against Hamas in retaliation for the deadliest attack in Israel's history.

title.children: Hamas accused of using Gaza residents as a 'shield' as Israeli ground invasion looms

image.altText: Jade Ellenger celebrates

items.synopsis: Brisbane kicked eight goals to down the Suns at Carrara and win the QClash. St Kilda have extended their AFLW winning streak to a club-record four games by defeating Greater Western Sydney, Geelong beats Fremantle, Essendon beats Richmond and Hawthorn power past Sydney.

title.children: Brisbane hammers Gold Coast in AFLW QClash

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

items.synopsis: A quick glance at the national forecast this weekend and you could be forgiven for questioning what season we're in. ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders explains what is driving the country's weather disparity.

title.children: Heat in the west and snow in the south-east — here's what is driving Australia's stark weather contrasts

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce, Michaelia Cash and Bridget McKenzie sitting in front of protesters at the national press club

items.synopsis: As Australians hit the polls to have their say in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum, here's a look back — in pictures — at how we got here.

title.children: In pictures: The Indigenous Voice to Parliament debate of 2023
